column1: Conversation

The CFPB issued an ANPR yesterday regarding the "QM Patch"which is set to expire in Jan. 2021. The industry knows this. The QM Patch allows DTI greater than 43% and if it expires, the business will go to the FHA instead of the PMI's. However, it is more likely that the rule/provision gets renewed and at a position more FAVORABLE for the PMI's. The Feds want more private capital not less. Big over reaction to news that could be viewed as a positive for the PMI industry.

I've looked back at the entire history of MGIC as a public company (but excluding the crisis years 2008-2012, when MTG might have gone bust). The LOWEST price-to-book ratio --at the calendar year high-- was 1.40x year-end book value. In other words, looking at the high and low stock price during a calendar year, vs. that same year-end book value. The low was in 2006, and match in 2016-- at 1.40x BV. 2019's year-end book value should approximate $12.25. 1.40x 12.25 BV gets you to a price of $17.15. The average high over the last 4 years (2015-2018) is 1.66x BV on the high end and 1.02 on the low end. 1.66x 12.25 is $>$20. And we've already had the low for th year price-wise at 10.20, which is 0.83x year-end BV. MTG should be trading at $17-20, not $13 and change.
Great quarter, now with those numbers in mind we know how much less money they will make because of their price cuts. Sad!
The board is silent, except for the daily Yahoo Finance notifications stating that MGIG is pulling a China Syndrome. But everybody’s out, right?

So MTG is trading at 92% of my estimate of year-end Book Value ($14.25). The 5-year average (using calendar year price high/low divided by book value) is 1.57x - 0.98. The lowest it ever traded at in the last 5 years was 73% of BV (in 2016, when MTG hit $5.44 and year-end 2016 BV was $7.48). That is a crisis type multiple. With stocks near 5-year highs, there is no reason why MTG should be trading below BV. The 5-year high was 1.84x BV, in 2017 when MTG traded at $15.64 and year-end 2017 BV was $8.51. 1.84x my estimate of year-end 2020 BV of $14.25 is $26/share, or a double from these levels! Realistically, downside is $11-- but upside is $26. My only question is what will be the catalyst to pop the stock higher? Buffett should be buying MTG but it's simply too small for him. Maybe he offers to take the company private.

MGIC Investment Corporation (NYSE: MTG) today reported operating and financial results for the third quarter of 2020. Net income for the quarter was $130.8 million , or $0.38 per diluted share, compared with net income of $176.9 million , or $0.49 per diluted share, for the third quarter of 2019.Adjusted net operating income for the third quarter of 2020 was $149 .9 million, or $0.43 per diluted share, compared with $173.6 million , or $0.48 per diluted share, for the third quarter of 2019. We present the non-GAAP financial measure "Adjusted net operating income" to increase the comparability between periods of our financial results.

Conference call October 14, 2018 highlights: 1) The main driver of our future revenues insurance in force grew nearly 8% over the last 12 months ending the quarter at nearly $206 billion.2) our new business writings are up about 6% to over $38 billion3) strong demand for housing as consumers especially those below the age of 454) the number of policies that were delinquent, as of the end of the third quarter has fallen to its lowest level since 1997.5) there are only six private mortgage insurers6) the third quarter, we earned $181.9 million of net income or $0.49 per diluted share compared to $120 million or $0.32 per diluted share in the same period last year.7) The effective average premium yield for the third quarter of 2018 was 49.3 basis points, which was approximately flat to last quarter.8) our consolidated cash and investments totaled $5.2 billion9) At the end of the third quarter, MGIC's statutory capital is $2.5 billion in excess of the state requirement.10) Currently, we have $100 million remaining under share repurchase program that does not expire until 2019 ( notice: i believe this tool was used when stock fell under book value)11) expect that our insurance in force will continue to grow due to the level of new business we expect to write and the strong persistency.12) we'll still have those discussions internally about dividends back to shareholders. But at this point, we are not ready to announce anything. (notice: here I strongly believe that if pps is above book value, it is better to use free money instead of buyback for paying the dividend)13) we’re just not to be able to make any comments about the ILN or potential implications of it. (notice: about ILN pls refer to this link http://www.artemis.bm/blog/2018/07/31/mgic-watching-as-mortgage-insurance-linked-note-market-hits-2-2bn/14) lower expense ratio is driven by the reserve release15) Still have very favorable views about housing in general across the country. And originators in this cycle do not control the credit box. The GSEs do and most of our business goes to GSE route. So the GSE is the one controlling the credit box. So mortgage market is not competing at credit this point in time, which is different than prior cycles. And I think that's very favorable. So we feel very, very good about where the market is right now both from a credit standpoint and from a housing standpoint.
No reason for this to be dropping

"Despite the economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, the housing market has been resilient and, given our market presence and the overall market size, we wrote $112.1 billion of new insurance in 2020, including $33.2 billion in the fourth quarter. As a result, insurance in force increased more than 10% year-over-year, despite the lower annual persistency associated with the strong refinance market. In 2020, we further strengthened our already strong capital and liquidity positions by reducing the amount of holding company debt due in 2023, increasing liquidity at our holding company, ceding additional risk through reinsurance transactions, and increasing MGIC's statutory and PMIERs capital positions." Mattke continued, "In 2020 our company wrote a record volume of new business while being challenged by the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, including higher losses incurred, especially in the second quarter of the year. I am very proud of our team members who remain focused on executing our business strategies and providing critical support for our customers and the housing market, especially for first-time homebuyers, as we all continue to navigate through the current environment."

MGIC Investment Q2 Results Top Street Views - Shares Up 5% Pre-Bell7:20 AM ET, 07/18/2018 - MT Newswires07:20 AM EDT, 07/18/2018 (MT Newswires) -- MGIC Investment (MTG) shares were 5% higher pre-market Wednesday after the home-mortgage insurer reported Q2 earnings and revenues above Street views, citing strong housing and employment trends, and declining mortgage delinquencies. MGIC reported Q2 adjusted EPS of $0.49, above the Street view of $0.36, as compiled by Capital IQ. A year earlier, the company reported a like figure of $0.31.MGIC reported Q2 revenue of $282.0 million, above the $270.0 million Street view, and up from $263.3 million reported a year earlier.

Does it make sense that MTG is down 19% in just 6 trading days?? Analyst estimates have been rising over the last 30, 60 and 90 days-- and are up substantially over the last 90 days. Stock near $12 is at 7.5x 2019 estimate. Company is in the best fiscal and financial shape in its history-- best capital cushion of all-time. Business is very healthy. And many secular tailwinds that should be in their favor over the next 3-5 years. Year-end Book Value (BV) should be around $10. And MTG has traded in a range of 1.8-1.15x year-end BV since 2013, with the one exception being early 2016. Aside from early 16, MTG has not traded below year-end BV since the company's solvency was in question during 2009-2012. My view is that we are close to the bottom here-- 1.15x year-end BV is $11.50/sh. High end target should be close to $18 during THIS year. 2019 BV could be $11.50, putting 2019 high target over $20. That's a 70%+ return between now and sometime in 2019.

MGIC Investment Corporation Releases Monthly Operating StatisticsJun 10, 2019MILWAUKEE, June 10, 2019 /PRNewswire/ -- MGIC Investment Corporation (NYSE: MTG) today issued an Operational Summary of its insurance subsidiaries for the month of May 2019 for their primary mortgage insurance. The summary is also available on the company's investor website under Newsroom, Press Releases.The information concerning new delinquency notices and cures is compiled from reports received from loan servicers. The level of new notice and cure activity reported in a particular month can be influenced by, among other things, the date on which a servicer generates its report, the accuracy of the data provided by servicers, the number of business days in a month, transfers of servicing between loan servicers, and whether all servicers have provided the reports in a given month.May 2019May 2018ChangeInsurance in force (billions)$213.3$199.37.0%Flow only$207.0$191.87.9%Beginning Primary Delinquent Inventory (# of loans)29,96238,845(22.9)%Plus: New Delinquency Notices4,3824,2154.0%Less: Cures4,2184,813(12.4)%Less: Paids372517(28.0)%Less: Rescissions and Denials1728(39.3)%Less: Items removed from inventory (1)—438N/MEnding Primary Delinquent Inventory (# of loans) (2)29,73737,264(20.2)%(1)Consists of loans whose insurance was terminated by agreement to settle coverage on certain non-performing loans. The agreement did not have a material financial impact.(2) May 2018 ending primary delinquent inventory was impacted by hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria, which occurred in August - September 2017. The number of loans in ending primary delinquent inventory from geographical areas that the Federal Emergency Management Agency declared Individual Assistance Disaster Areas as a result of those hurricanes was 4,648 in May 2019, 8,690 in May 2018, and 6,032 in May 2017.

FINALLY I found out why MTG has been trading off since 12/22. MTG talked about the proposed changes to PMIERS requirements that are being recommended by the GSE's: "If the GSE-recommended changes are adopted with an effective date in the fourth quarter of 2018, we expect that at the effective date, Mortgage Guaranty Insurance Corporation would continue to have an excess of 'Available Assets' over 'Minimum Required Assets,' although this excess would be materially lower than it was at September 30, 2017 under the existing PMIERs, and that MGIC would continue to be able to pay quarterly dividends to our holding company at the $50 million quarterly rate at which they were paid in the fourth quarter of 2017. As a result, we expect cash at our holding company during the fourth quarter of 2018 would increase over what it is expected to be at December 31, 2017. We have non-disclosure obligations to each of the GSEs and cannot provide any further comment on the specific provisions of the GSE-recommended changes other than as described above."

In 1994, as the US was coming off the recession of 1990-91, MTG had a BV of $7.18/sh. Stock traded that year in a range of 17.13-12.50. In 2 years, in 1996, BV went to $11.59/sh and MTG traded in a range of 38.88-25.81. In 1997, MTG hit $67/sh. Remember that housing was really bad from 1990-93, in fact 1993 was a great time to buy residential real estate. I see a lot of parallels to that today.
